page.title: 07FARMING ON THE S.DOWNS
page.content: Farming on the S.Downs has changed radically since the 1939-45 war. Formerly the downs were used for grazing sheep but the powerful new machinery made after the war made ploughing of the top of the downs possible; the turf disappeared & with it the sheep. As a result of these changes almost all the downland turf was lost, so that the land is now scattered with flints & broken chalk. The disappearance of the sheep allowed the rough grasses & scrub to spread, so that small flowers no longer flourish; bushes & trees now cover much of the steep northern slopes. Many mature beech trees were felled to make way for cereal crops & large areas on the southern slopes were planted with conifers.
